title: 110_hr1497
content: The "Legal Timber Protection Act" aims to prevent illegal logging practices. The Lacey Act Amendments of 1981 define the term "plant" as any wild member of the plant kingdom, excluding common food crops or cultivars not listed in certain international agreements or as endangered species. The Lacey Act Amendments of 1981 define "take" as capturing, killing, collecting, and also harvesting, cutting, logging, or removing plants in violation of state or foreign laws protecting plants. The Lacey Act Amendments of 1981 define "take" as the unauthorized removal of plants from protected areas or designated areas, without required authorization or payment of fees, in violation of state or foreign laws. The Lacey Act Amendments of 1981 prohibit the possession of plants taken in violation of state or foreign laws that protect plants or regulate their theft from protected areas. The Lacey Act Amendments of 1981 prohibit the possession of plants taken in violation of state or foreign laws that protect plants or regulate their theft from protected areas. The amendments also address the unauthorized taking, transportation, or export of plants without required authorization or payment of royalties, taxes, or fees. Additionally, the amendments prohibit the export or transshipment of plants in violation of any state or foreign law. Plant Declarations are required under the amendments. Effective 180 days after enactment, it will be illegal to import any plant without filing a declaration containing the scientific name, value, quantity, and country of origin. Until the Secretary promulgates a regulation, a declaration for plant products must include the names of all possible plant species used and the country of origin if unknown. The Secretary must review the implementation of requirements for plant product declarations within 2 years of enactment, and submit a report within 180 days after completion of the review. The Secretary is required to submit a report to Congress evaluating the effectiveness of information required for enforcement and recommending appropriate legislation. The Secretary must conduct a review to identify plants imported into the US in violation of section 3, analyze the impact of certain provisions on legal plant imports and illegal logging practices, and allow for public participation. Regulations must be issued within 180 days. The Secretary may promulgate regulations within 180 days to limit requirements to specific plant products, make necessary modifications, and adjust exclusion scope based on a review. Section 7(a)(1) is amended to include section 3(f) and section 4. Section 4 may undergo changes as determined by the Secretary. In section 4 of the Lacey Act Amendments, subsections (b) and (d) are replaced with subsections (b), (d), and (f). Section 3(f) is added after section 3(d) in multiple instances. Civil forfeitures under section 5 will follow the provisions of chapter 46 of title 18, United States Code. Additionally, a technical correction is made to Section 102(c) of Public Law 100-653. The Lacey Act Amendments of 1981 are amended by inserting "of the Lacey Act Amendments of 1981" after "Section 4" and by updating subsection references. The effective date is tied to the effectiveness of section 102(c) of Public Law 100-653.
